The study of the size and shape of metal nanoclusters has
evolved since its infancy two decades ago. Table
In the Table, we list primarily transition metals, not
alloys or compounds, with the exception of the truncated
has been more synthesis of gold clusters than any other
element, due to its properties and stability. In the sub-
sections which follow, we limit our discussion to specific
topics related to magic formulas and types of clusters.
Magic formulas for the bcc tetrahedron
Magic formulas for the diamond cubic
Eight of the transition metals crystallize in the fcc struc-
metals and important catalytically active elements. The
vast majority of nanocluster synthesis has been with
these elements. References of the synthesis of the fcc
elements with various shapes and sizes is given in
Alloys of these elements are also of interest, but ref-
erences of these are too numerous to be cited here.
Frequently, the common shapes synthesized are cubes,
octahedra, cuboctahedra, and icosahedra. Typically, clus-
ters with (111) facets are easier to synthesize, since the
(111) surface usually has a lower energy than the (100)
]. We find for the fcc rhombic dodecahedron
that there exist even and odd formulas. These agree with
. The formulas for fcc cuboctahedra listed
] produce the same magic numbers as ours but are
shifted by 1 since they number shells as
], and in deference to the ear-
lier published work, and in maintaining continuity of the
shapes and their associated magic formulas appear below.
Seven of the transition metals in the periodic table have
ments Fe, Co, and Ni, only iron is bcc. Nanocubes of iron
appear to be the only bcc cluster shape synthesized so far
Magic formulas for the simple cubic
